title: `rustdoc --test` erroneously turns text into doc test and fails

labels.name: T-rustdoc
labels.description: Relevant to the rustdoc team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: A-doctests
labels.description: Area: Documentation tests, run by rustdoc

body:
I apologize in advance if I'm misunderstanding the expected behavior here, but here goes.  I've got a file with these contents:

```rust
/*!
 * * Hello
 *     * World
 *
  * Lorem
 */
```

This is a little weird, but it's the minimum case I found to reproduce the issue.  The unusual leading space on line 5 is important.  (If you're wondering how I got here, it was from [rustfmt issue 4079](https://github.com/rust-lang/rustfmt/issues/4079).)

I expected that if I ran `rustdoc --test`, I would find that it passed after having run 0 tests, since there doesn't appear to be a doc test here.

But `rustdoc --test` reports:

```
$ rustdoc --version
rustdoc 1.41.0 (5e1a79984 2020-01-27)
$ rustdoc --test issue.rs 

running 1 test
test issue.rs -  (line 2) ... FAILED

failures:

---- issue.rs -  (line 2) stdout ----
error[E0425]: cannot find value `World` in this scope
 --> issue.rs:3:3
  |
3 | * World
  |   ^^^^^ not found in this scope

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0425`.
Couldn't compile the test.

failures:
    issue.rs -  (line 2)

test result: FAILED. 0 passed; 1 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out

$ 
```

`rustdoc` seems to have extracted a doc test that includes the chunk of the comment on line 3.

I see the same behavior with the nightly I have installed:

```
$ rustdoc +nightly --version
rustdoc 1.43.0-nightly (158127853 2020-03-10)
$ rustdoc +nightly --test issue.rs 

running 1 test
test issue.rs -  (line 3) ... FAILED

failures:

---- issue.rs -  (line 3) stdout ----
error[E0425]: cannot find value `World` in this scope
 --> issue.rs:4:3
  |
3 | * World
  |   ^^^^^ not found in this scope

error: aborting due to previous error

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0425`.
Couldn't compile the test.

failures:
    issue.rs -  (line 3)

test result: FAILED. 0 passed; 1 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out

```

You can reproduce this yourself here:
https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=051d1b04c88609b3dd4140956374a788

Now, you might think this is okay behavior because line 3 includes a leading 4 spaces that could cause it to be treated as a code block.  I think that's not right for a few reasons:

1. The [CommonMark spec for indented code blocks](https://spec.commonmark.org/0.29/#indented-code-blocks) says "there must be a blank line between a paragraph and a following indented code block."  It also says "If there is any ambiguity between an interpretation of indentation as a code block and as indicating that material belongs to a list item, the list item interpretation takes precedence."
2. To test this, I took lines 2-4, dropped the leading " *", and put them into the CommonMark "dingus" tool, which [renders it as a list, not an indented code block](https://spec.commonmark.org/dingus/?text=%20*%20Hello%0A%20%20%20%20%20*%20World%0A%0A).
3. The real kicker is that if you take the exact same example and remove the leading space on **line 5**, then the example works:

```
$ diff issue.rs non-issue.rs 
5c5
<   * Lorem
---
>  * Lorem
$ rustdoc --test non-issue.rs 

running 0 tests

test result: ok. 0 passed; 0 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out
```

I'm not sure how that change to line 5 affects how line 3 gets parsed.
